content.sub_section: Equity Market
Equity Market
Equity Market
Equity Market
content.text: Indian benchmark equity indices witnessed marginal gains during the month. Markets corrected during the early part of May 2025 due

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: to escalating tensions between India and Pakistan, following India’s launch of ‘Operation Sindoor’ targeting terrorist infrastructure in

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: Pakistan and Pakistan-occupied Jammu and Kashmir. However, sentiment improved thereafter as tensions eased.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: The Nifty 50 and BSE Sensex indices posted monthly gains of 1.7% and 1.5%, respectively, in May 2025. However, the benchmark

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: indices remain down by approximately 5-6% from their peak. Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs) continued to remain net buyers for

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: the second consecutive month with a net inflow of US$2.3 billion. Meanwhile, Domestic Institutional Investors (DIIs) bought US$7.9

content.sub_section: Equity Market
Equity Market
content.text: The broader market indices' performance was comparatively much better, with BSE MidCap and BSE SmallCap reporting monthly

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: gains of 5.3% and 10.6%, respectively. Among the sector indices, Defence, Industrials, Real Estate and Metals outperformed with

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: month gains of 21.8%, 14.3%, 7.2% and 5.9%, respectively. However, Utilities and FMCG underperformed with monthly losses of

content.sub_section: Equity Market
Equity Market
content.text: India’s real GDP growth accelerated to 7.4% YoY in Q4FY25 from 6.4% in the previous quarter. In Q4FY25, the agriculture sector

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: recorded healthy growth of 5.4%, supported by strong agricultural output. The manufacturing sector’s growth further recovered

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: to 4.8% YoY from 3.6% YoY in the previous quarter. Services sector growth remained resilient as weakness in the Trade+ segment

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: was more than offset by strong construction activity and improvement in the Financial Services+ segment. Private consumption

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: growth slowed to 6.0% YoY in Q4FY25 from 8.1% in the previous quarter, as indicators point to subdued urban consumption. Fixed

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: investment growth rebounded to 9.4% YoY in Q4 from 5.2% in Q3 as government capital expenditure picked up.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: For FY25, real GDP growth eased to 6.5% YoY from 9.2% in the previous year. Nominal GDP growth declined to 9.8% YoY in FY25

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: from 12% YoY in FY24, as weaker real GDP growth outweighed the impact of a higher GDP deflator (inflation). On the production

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: side, the manufacturing sector witnessed the steepest decline in its contribution to GDP growth in FY25, while on the expenditure

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: side, fixed investment experienced the sharpest drop in contribution, followed by government consumption.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: India’s Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation eased to 3.16% YoY in April 2025 from 3.34% in the previous month. The decline in

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: headline inflation was driven by a fall in food inflation to 2.1% YoY in April 2025 from 2.9% YoY in March 2025. Core inflation (which

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: excludes food and fuel) remained flat at 4.2% YoY.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: The IMD has updated the forecast for the Southwest Monsoon to 106% of the long-period average, up from the previous 105%. The

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: IMD assigned a 59% likelihood to an above-normal or excess monsoon, a 31% chance of a normal monsoon, and only a 10% chance

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: of it being below normal or deficient.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
Equity Market
content.text: The reciprocal tariffs announced on 2nd April pose a significant threat to global growth. These measures are likely to drive inflation

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: in the United States and disrupt global trade flows. While India is relatively better positioned than many other countries, which may

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: face steeper tariffs, its exports to the US are still expected to come under pressure due to a slowdown in the US economy. However,

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: merchandise exports to the US amount to only 2% of GDP, which limits the impact of tariffs. With significant uncertainty surrounding

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: the implementation of tariffs and their potential impact on global trade, the equity risk premium has the potential to rise across

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: markets. Hence, investors should prepare for further volatility.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: The domestic macro environment is turning conducive to an economic recovery. First, income tax reductions will increase consumers'

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: disposable income, benefiting consumption-driven sectors, particularly discretionary consumption. Second, food inflation is expected

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: to remain benign due to robust agricultural production, which will further support consumption. Third, more interest rate cuts are

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: expected in 2025 to stimulate the economy. Fourth, regulatory easing is also underway, with the RBI reversing the November 2023

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: hike in risk weights for bank loans to NBFCs and microfinance consumer credit loans.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: Looking ahead, we expect key shifts in market trends:

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: • Growth leadership is shifting from government capital expenditures to consumer discretionary spending.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: • After an outperformance of around three years, Value may take a back seat, and Quality and growth factors may regain favour.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: Looking ahead, discretionary consumption is expected to rise, driven by budget stimulus for the urban middle class, followed by a

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: pay commission-related boost next year. Additionally, liquidity easing, accompanied by rate cuts, would create a favourable

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: premise for growth and quality to come back.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: • In our portfolios, we have been shifting some weight from Value to quality and growth over the last year.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: Several high-growth areas have strong value-creation potential. Key segments include auto EV plays, manufacturing, and pharma

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: CDMO. The power transmission, distribution, and renewable energy sectors also present significant opportunities. Quick commerce

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: is an emerging sector expected to experience exponential growth over the next five years. Additionally, telecom and high-quality

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: private banks remain attractive value segments.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: We have consistently maintained a more favourable stance towards inward-looking sectors driven by domestic fundamentals, rather

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: than those reliant on external or global factors. Our outlook continues to reflect this preference, as we believe domestic-oriented

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: sectors offer greater resilience and stability amid global uncertainties.

content.sub_section: Equity Market
content.text: Source: CMIE, Bloomberg and Internal research

content.text: India’s Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation eased to 3.16% YoY in April 2025 from 3.34% in the previous month. The
decline in headline inflation was driven by a fall in food inflation to 2.1% YoY in April 2025 from 2.9% YoY in March
2025. Within food, a lower contribution from vegetables drove the decline in headline inflation. Vegetable inflation
eased to -11.0% YoY in April 2025 from -7.0% YoY in March, on account of a 3.0% MoM correction in vegetable prices.
Core inflation (which excludes food and fuel) remained flat at 4.2% YoY. Underlying inflation pressures remained
subdued, as indicated by a refined measure of core inflation (which additionally excludes transportation fuel and
valuables), measuring 3.5% YoY in April 2025. The inflation outlook remains benign and especially in the next 6
months headline CPI will benefit from a big base effect as well.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) announced an all-time high dividend transfer of Rs 2.69 trillion to the Government
of India. Furthermore, the revised range for the Contingency Risk Buffer (CRB) has been decided at 6.0 ± 1.5% of the
balance sheet size (as against the existing level of 6.5%- 5.5%) – as part of the periodic review of the Economic Capital
Framework. The CRB has been raised to 7.5%.
The IMD has updated the forecast for the Southwest Monsoon to 106% (+/- 4%) of the long-period average (LPA), up
from the previous 105% (+/- 5%). During June to September 2025, normal to above normal rainfall is very likely over
most parts of the country, except some areas of Northwest and East India and many areas of Northeast India, where
below normal rainfall is very likely.  The average rainfall for the country as a whole during June 2025 is most likely
to be above normal (>108% of LPA).
In FY25, direct tax collection rose by 13% YoY to Rs. 21.7 tn, up from Rs. 19.2 tn in FY24 but fell short of the revised
target of Rs. 22.4 tn by Rs. 673 bn, primarily due to a Rs. 740 bn shortfall in personal income tax. Disinvestment
proceeds remained weak at Rs. 172 bn, well below the Rs. 330 bn target. Revenue expenditure increased by 3.1%
YoY to Rs. 36 tn, lower than the revised estimate of Rs. 37 tn, while capital expenditure exceeded the target by Rs.

content.sub_section: Debt Market

Debt Market
content.text: While dovish policy continued in euro region (with another 25bps rate cut expectation in June) and China as PBoC cut

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: key lending rates to record lows and reduced the reserve requirement ratio by 50bps.

content.sub_section: Debt Market
Debt Market
content.text: Despite significant volatility in global debt markets, domestic yields declined sharply last month. RBI continues to

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: make largescale purchase of government securities from the secondary market as part of its operations to infuse

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: liquidity into the banking system. Indian Fixed income markets remained supported in the month of May despite

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: adverse global cues. The US yields climbed higher due to fiscal worries and firmer-than-expected economic activity

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: data deferring interest rate cut expectations by the Fed. The UST 10Y yield has risen ~24 bps mom, closing the month

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: of May at 4.40% (reaching highs of 4.63% during the month). Domestically, bond markets have rallied, barring the

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: Indo-Pak border escalation episode. Favourable CPI inflation trends and record dividend announcement by the RBI

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: supported the bond markets, though higher than expected GDP growth print at the end of the last week weighed on

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: the bond market sentiments. The new benchmark 10Y G-sec is trading ~11 bps lower at around 6.21% since its issue.

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: FPIs also continued inflows worth ~10k crores after profit booking in April.

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: Average banking system liquidity surplus stood at Rs 1.7 lakh crore till mid-month and improved to ~2.2 lakh crore till

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: the close of the month. RBI infused liquidity in the markets through Open Market Operations (OMOs) of Rs. 1.25 lakh

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: crore exceeding market estimates on OMOs pushing the yield curve lower. We expect durable liquidity in the ~Rs5-6

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: trillion range over the next few months, with the flow of funds to the banking system expected to come with a lag as

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: government spending picks up pace. we expect cash balances to moderate to around Rs2.7 trillion driven by debt

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: buyback and continued government spending. Money market rates eased by 30bps across the 3-month to 1-year

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: tenure favouring corporates and NBFC borrowers with risk premium narrowing with large infuse of liquidity. We think

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: market has already priced in two rate cuts both in bonds and OIS markets, also spreads compressed between the

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: G-sec and corporate bonds as investors subscribed for better accrual specially in the short-medium term yield curve

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: i.e. 2–5-year maturity. The narrowing spread between the US treasury and India’s G-secs (at 165 bps it has narrowed

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: by roughly three-quarters) may act as a deterrent for the yields to soften further significantly further add complexity

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: of Japan rising yield and inflation. It is important to disentangle whether the narrowing gap is primarily due to India’s

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: improving macroeconomic fundamentals or external developments like US monetary policy shifts. In truth, it is a

content.sub_section: Debt Market
Debt Market
Debt Market
content.text: Softening global commodity prices, above- normal rainfall expectations and probable improvement in agricultural

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: output helping headline inflation remain benign. Combined with expectations of decline in the U.S. dollar index and

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: anticipated rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve create further room for monetary easing in India leading to further

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: decline in domestic yields in the coming months. We expect the Indian benchmark 10-year bond yield to trade in the

content.sub_section: Debt Market
content.text: 6.10-6.30% range taking into consideration scope for a deeper rate cut cycle and continued easy liquidity.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: An employee of the asset management company such as a mutual fund or life insurer, who manages investments of the scheme. He is usually part of a

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: larger team of fund managers and research analysts.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: This is the minimum investment amount for a new investor in a mutual fund scheme.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: This is the minimum investment amount for an existing investor in a mutual fund scheme.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: The Yield to Maturity or the YTM is the rate of return anticipated on a bond if held until maturity. YTM is expressed as an annual rate. The YTM factors in

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: the bond's current market price, par value, coupon interest rate and time to maturity.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: SIP or systematic investment plan works on the principle of making periodic investments of a fixed sum. It works similar to a recurring bank deposit. For

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: instance, an investor may opt for an SIP that invests ` 500 every 15th of the month in an equity fund for a period of three years.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: The NAV or the net asset value is the total asset value per unit of the mutual fund after deducting all related and permissible expenses. The NAV is

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: calculated at the end of every business day. It is the value at which the investor enters or exits the mutual fund.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: A group of securities, usually a market index, whose performance is used as a standard or benchmark to measure investment performance of mutual

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: funds, among other investments. Some typical benchmarks include the Nifty, Sensex, BSE200, BSE500, 10-Year Gsec.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: A mutual fund may have a sales charge or load at the time of entry and/or exit to compensate the distributor/agent. Entry load is charged at the time an

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: investor purchases the units of a mutual fund. The entry load is added to the prevailing NAV at the time of investment. For instance, if the NAV is ` 100

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: and the entry load is 1 %, the investor will enter the fund at ` 101.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: Exit load is charged at the time an investor redeems the units of a mutual fund. The exit load is deducted from the prevailing NAV at the time of

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: redemption. For instance, if the NAV is ` 100 and the exit load is 1%, the redemption price would be `99 per unit.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: Modified duration is the price sensitivity and the percentage change in price for a unit change in yield.

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: Standard deviation is a statistical measure of the range of an investment's performance. When a mutual fund has a high standard deviation, its means its

content.sub_section: GLOSSARY OF TERMS
content.text: range of performance is wide, implying greater volatility.

An employee of the asset management company such as a mutual fund or life insurer, who manages investments of the scheme. He is usually part of a
larger team of fund managers and research analysts.
This is the minimum investment amount for a new investor in a mutual fund scheme.
This is the minimum investment amount for an existing investor in a mutual fund scheme.

The Yield to Maturity or the YTM is the rate of return anticipated on a bond if held until maturity. YTM is expressed as an annual rate. The YTM factors in
the bond's current market price, par value, coupon interest rate and time to maturity.

SIP or systematic investment plan works on the principle of making periodic investments of a fixed sum. It works similar to a recurring bank deposit. For
instance, an investor may opt for an SIP that invests ` 500 every 15th of the month in an equity fund for a period of three years.

The NAV or the net asset value is the total asset value per unit of the mutual fund after deducting all related and permissible expenses. The NAV is
calculated at the end of every business day. It is the value at which the investor enters or exits the mutual fund.

A group of securities, usually a market index, whose performance is used as a standard or benchmark to measure investment performance of mutual
funds, among other investments. Some typical benchmarks include the Nifty, Sensex, BSE200, BSE500, 10-Year Gsec.

A mutual fund may have a sales charge or load at the time of entry and/or exit to compensate the distributor/agent. Entry load is charged at the time an
investor purchases the units of a mutual fund. The entry load is added to the prevailing NAV at the time of investment. For instance, if the NAV is ` 100
and the entry load is 1 %, the investor will enter the fund at ` 101.

Exit load is charged at the time an investor redeems the units of a mutual fund. The exit load is deducted from the prevailing NAV at the time of
redemption. For instance, if the NAV is ` 100 and the exit load is 1%, the redemption price would be `99 per unit.
Modified duration is the price sensitivity and the percentage change in price for a unit change in yield.

Standard deviation is a statistical measure of the range of an investment's performance. When a mutual fund has a high standard deviation, its means its
range of performance is wide, implying greater volatility.

The Sharpe Ratio, named after its founder, the Nobel Laureate William Sharpe, is a measure of risk-adjusted returns. It is calculated using
standard deviation and excess return to determine reward per unit of risk.

Beta is a measure of an investment's volatility vis-a-vis the market. Beta of less than 1 means that the security will be less volatile than the market. A beta
of greater than 1 implies that the security's price will be more volatile than the market.

R-squared measures the relationship between a portfolio and its benchmark index. It measures the correlation of the portfolio's returns to the
benchmark's returns.

Developed by Jack Treynor, the Treynor ratio (also known as the "reward-to-volatility ratio") attempts to measure how well an investment has
compensated its investors given its level of risk. The Treynor ratio relies on beta, which measures an investment's sensitivity to market
movements, to gauge risk.

AUM or assets under management refers to the recent I updated cumulative market value of investments managed by a mutual fund or any investment
firm.
Means the annualized standard deviation of the difference in daily returns between the underlying index and the NAV of the Scheme.
Means the annualized difference of daily returns between the index and the NAV of the Scheme.

The holdings or the portfolio is a mutual fund's latest or updated reported statement of investments/securities. These are usually displayed in terms
of percentage to net assets or the rupee value or both. The objective is to give investors an idea of where their money is being invested by the fund
manager.

The investment objective and underlying investments determine the nature of the mutual fund scheme. For instance, a mutual fund that aims at generat-
ing capital appreciation by investing in stock markets is an equity fund or growth fund. Likewise, a mutual fund that aims at capital preservation by
investing in debt markets is a debt fund or income fund. Each of these categories may have sub-categories.

Mutual funds invest in securities after evaluating their creditworthiness as disclosed by the ratings. A depiction of the mutual fund in various investments
based on their ratings becomes the rating profile of the fund. Typically, this is a feature of debt funds.
Dividend option is renamed as Income Distribution cum Capital Withdrawal (IDCW) option for all Schemes effective from April 1, 2021
